newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Crowds pack Sydney for gay Mardi Gras.
newsitem.headline: Crowds pack Sydney for gay Mardi Gras.

text.p: Hundreds of thousands of people packed central Sydney on Saturday night for the city's annual Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras parade, the culmination of a month of events celebrating homosexuality.

A record 200 floats joined the parade, featuring g-stringed male "brides" carrying red bouquets, nuns on in-line skates, hairy bears and a four-metre high effigy of Australian race row parliamentarian Pauline Hanson.
The parade, which mixes pointed political comment and bawdy humour, also featured a large "remembrance group" marching in memory of AIDS victims.
"The gay community has been ravaged by AIDS since the 1980s and this is a celebration of their lives," said Mardi Gras president Bev Lange.

Other attractions in the parade were the lesbian cycling group Dykes on Bikes and movie idol drag queens. A 13-year-old who says he was made an outcast at school for revealing his sexuality marched in school uniform.
Police said the crowds, which they estimated at over half a million, were "rowdy but generally well-behaved".
